ratings.question_text: The readings/cases/textbooks used in this course were __________ .
Out-of-class assignments for this course were ___________ to my learning.
The workload for this course in comparison to other courses was ___________.
The pace of this class was ____________ for optimal learning.
Field trips were well designed and ran smoothly.
I learned a lot from field trips.
How clearly does the instructor provide explanations of conceptual material?
How responsive to student comments was the instructor?
I would give the instructor of this class an overall rating of:
I would give this course an overall rating of:
Apart from how well the course was taught, how valuable is the course to students with interests similar to yours?
Did you participate in a work group as part of this course?

narratives.question_text: Use the space below to comment on questions 1-14, if you wish
comments: This was the best class I've taken at FES and I wish there were more courses like it.
the course really taught me interdisciplinary aspects of science, ecology and religion

narratives.question_text: What were the best aspects of this course?
comments: The in-class discussions with my wonderfully bright fellow students.
The discussions and videos
The discussions in this class offer the most value to the students. I understand why the course will be moving toward an online system, but I definitely loved the discussions.
challenging me to think differently about conservation issues

I really enjoyed the emphasis on the community of the course and the space that it gave us to talk about our personal experiences with the issues of the course. The openness of the final project was really wonderful--it made me think about what I wanted to do with my life and what I value.

The course gave students the opportunity to ask big picture questions about the universe, the environment and themselves.I think the class size was far larger than optimal for discussion, but the professors did an excellent job of facilitating given this challenge.The course attracted students with diverse backgrounds and discussion provided an excellent opportunity to hear a range of perspectives from other students.
interdisciplinary

This course renewed my energy and optimism about the trajectory of our planet. It reminded me that other parts of the globe still value the environment from an intuitive, intrinsic perpective - one that doesn't rely on logic and cost-benefit anaylsis to make decisions. Our class discussions were so inspiring and enlightening, and it seemed like every student cohort - the foresters, divinity, SOM, and undergraduate students - could participate in varying degrees as the course progressed while learning equally from each other's expertise. Going to class was a joy. This was more than a class. It was a community.

Professor Tucker and Professor Grim have a contagious enthusiasm for the course material, and life in general. They are excellent facilitators of class discussion. They offer unique and rich perspectives to FES that are not represented in other courses, the final project allows students to pursue their own passions and interests in creative ways.

narratives.question_text: What aspects of this course need the most improvement?
comments: Half the readings would do the job.
The Confucianism parts of the course are extremely confusing. I had very little idea of what was going on most of the time during those two weeks.

it was difficult to create and implement a project based on what we were currently learning or hadn't learn yet. I would recommend allowing projects that were based on something earlier in the semester or read Journey of the Universe in the beginning of the semester and use that as a reference to evaluate the remaining readings.
Either define the religion jargon or don't use it. Discussions about specific theories or passages from religious texts were completely lost on me
There were a lot of readings--it was hard to finish them all every week. Also, the selection of religions discussed felt a little random.
A smaller class size would be great, however I don't think it is worth limiting the class size because there is not another course at FES like it.I think a field trip or two would be very cool.
no comment

It might be helpful to provide a little more upfront guidance for our Journey of the Universe projects. If the professors explicitly stated upfront that this project is purposely open-ended and relatively unstructured, then students might feel a little less apprehensive and confused about the project expectations. This might start the creative process a little sooner as students encounter the universe story. In fact, it might be important for students to know that project inspiration may take several weeks to emerge as the universe story unfolds after spring break.
Some concepts and terms could be explained more thoroughly in future classes. For students like myself without a background in religion, some of these concepts were unclear.

narratives.question_text: Was the relationship between the course lectures and discussion/lab section
comments: Everything was perfect.
na
NA
it was effective.

Yes, this was very effective, particularly because we led the discussion. Having the summaries for reference online was also helpful, especially because students often gravitated towards material with which they were most familiar or interested. That illuminated the information even more, and drew on each student's strength and energy.

narratives.question_text: Discuss, if you wish, how this course fits into your overall program.  (Please feel free to describe how the course relates to your academic background.)
comments: It is more of a capstone class for the end of my stay here at Yale. Infact, i can confidently say it is the right class to cap off all the years of education i have had.

I am very interested in environmental issues, and I wanted to understand them from a religious perspective. I am not religious, and this class showed me how to look at these global issues from a variety of perspectives.
I am interested in the human dimensions of conservation which religion is a large part of. I had no prior experience in this area of study.
If there were more classes like it, this course would be the focus of my program.
it fits well.
This course expanded and enriched my worldview in a very positive way, and that's a profound benefit that will continually inspire me in my coursework ahead.

This course was my first exposure academically to religion/cosmology. It provided me inspiration to continue on with my professional path in the environmental field and helped me learn more about what resources exist to inspire others.

narratives.question_text: Why did you take this course?
comments: Im am interested in human views and values on nature and this course was a perfect fit.
Understand how religions affect us and our ethics.
I had heard amazing things about Professors Grim and Tucker. Plus the material and syllabus looked fascinating.
I liked the dynamic conversations that were encouraged. It was a challenge for me, felt like learning a new language from time to time.
I took the course because of my academic interests in environmental issues, and because of my spiritual interests as well. The course felt important--like a one of a kind opportunity.
The kind of thinking and big picture questions raised in the course get at the root of our environmental issues in a way that other courses ignore. I was excited and relieved to find this course.
my interest in interdisciplinary subject
It just felt right. I intuitively knew this course would affect me in a profound way.

Much of my motivation to pursue a career path in the environmental field comes from religion/cosmology. I wanted to learn more about these sources of inspiration in an academic environment. I found this unique opportunity in this class.

narratives.question_text: Did the knowledge/skills that you gained from the course meet your expectations ?
comments: YES!Still, I would have preferred to discuss more religions (Taoism, Hinduism, Buddhism, Islam...).
Yes.

yes. It was incredible and I think I would even get more out of taking the class again. I wish I recorded the discussions particularly Professor Grim's comments just to listen to again to see what else I can get from his insight.
yes

When we talked about religions, I got a little bit lost in the theoretical discussions of the religions. It felt a little bit too academic, and I came out of it knowing a little less than I expected to about the religions. But the portion about Journey more than met my expectations. I never expected that to affect me so much.

Yes, most emphatically yes. I became more adept at expressing myself succintly, using new types of language to express environmental values and morals, and gained confidence in the importance of these elements within F&ES and outside of the school
Yes. I appreciate that I had the opportunity to connect with other students over these issues.
yea it did
Yes, but students should know that this isn't a "skill" course. It goes well beyond that.

Yes. I had hoped to explore the ecological foundations of various religions, ESP Christianity, and this course provided an avenue to do so. While I had not expected to learn about the universe story, I found this portion of the class very inspiring.

narratives.question_text: If yes, what were the advantages and disadvantages of the group work?
comments: na
NA

narratives.question_text: For students who might consider taking this course, what advice would you give them?
comments: Don't just consider taking the course - do it! You won't regret it.
Everyone at FES should be made to take this course.
Participate in class!
Don't be afraid to voice your opinion. The professors may challenge you but its done in a constructive way.
Be a free spirit

I would say--get to know your classmates. It's just a unique mix of people and knowing them will make class discussions more valuable. Read Journey and think about the final project early if you can, so you can do something really cool with it.
TAKE IT! Don't miss the opportunity. It will inform what you do in the long run no matter what that is.
need background knowledge on religion and ecology. course also demands speaking. so the course is excellent for improving speaking skills

Come in with an open mind and heart. Do not write this course off because it doesn't fit snugly into your professional goals. Chances are that you won't remember most of your courses' material in ten years. You'll definitely remember this course, however.
Take this course! Professor Tucker amid Professor Grim have such beautiful, unique voices - it'd be a shame to miss the opportunity to miss learning from them.
